title: 106_s2554
content: This Act, known as "Amy Boyer's Law," prohibits the display of Social Security numbers to the general public for commercial purposes without consent. It amends Part A of title XI of the Social Security Act to prevent certain misuses of Social Security numbers. Sec. 1150A prohibits the public display of social security numbers without consent and prohibits the wrongful use of these numbers for harmful or illegal purposes. Consent must be obtained by informing individuals of the purposes for displaying their social security numbers. Sec. 1150A requires informing individuals of the purposes and recipients of their social security numbers and obtaining their consent electronically or in writing. Exceptions include permitted uses under specific laws and do not affect the Fair Credit Reporting Act or the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. Sec. 1150A prohibits or limits the use of social security numbers for retrieving information without displaying them to the public, for law enforcement purposes, and for obtained numbers from public records. Individuals aggrieved by violations can bring a civil action in a US district court for relief. The court may grant preliminary relief and award damages in civil actions for violations of Sec. 1150A, including actual or liquidated damages of $2,500 or $10,000 for willful violations. Attorney's fees and costs may be assessed against the respondent if the aggrieved individual substantially prevails. No action can be commenced beyond the statute of limitations. Any person who violates this section may be subject to civil money penalties of up to $5,000 for each violation and up to $50,000 for multiple violations. Enforcement procedures apply to civil money penalties under this subsection in the same manner as other penalties under section 1128A. The Commissioner of Social Security is responsible for coordinating the enforcement of section 1128A with criminal enforcement under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Cooperative arrangements with the Federal Trade Commission are established for this purpose. The amendment made by subsection (a) of the Act of 1998 prohibits states from imposing requirements or prohibitions on subjects regulated under subsections (a) through (d). It defines "display to the general public" as the intentional placement of an individual's social security number in a viewable manner on a public website or in material available to the public. The amendment applies to violations occurring two years after the enactment of the Act.
